Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: how to think about things from a historical, and not political, lens; tons of information regarding recent history; stories that usually go untold
Learned so much about the social, political, cultural, economic, (and many more) factors that have shaped our world circa 2000 and the way these factors interconnect.

This course was a great, broad survey of recent history around the globe. I particularly appreciated that the course covered a series of movements, events, and developments that are often not discussed in-depth in other history classes - the history of narcotics, trade unions, and the incel movement for instance. The course was also structured such that you could largely work at your own pace and dive into topics you're actually interested in for the blog posts.
I learned a lot of about the modern world
Waste of a class. I learned nothing.

A very broad survey knowledge of colonialism, postcolonialism, hippies, revolutions, sexual revolutions, American leftist organizations, Cuba and Fidel Castro, "the Global South", Chinese infrastructure investments in Africa, Buddhism and counterculture spiritual movements, development aid economics, and the CIA. Interesting stuff.

Wonderful class! I loved the lectures and the assignments. It was incredibly engaging and I learned so much about world history, interactions of race and economics, and last but not least- a surprising amount about healthcare in the world.

I'm not really sure what I learned in this course.  Every lecture was a different topic, and it was difficult to tell how they all fit together. In general, this class was very anti-west, so much so that I felt the professors lacked credibility by the end of the course because of their bias. In fact, I found the professors to be pseudo-intellectual moralizers. The typical lecture went as follows: begin with some story about a random person, spend 20+ minutes talking about irrelevant details in their life, finally move into actual material, and spend the last 5 minutes cramming in all of the actual points that need to be made. I am very disappointed in the presentation of this course, and I strongly recommend it is reorganized for future offerings.
This class taught me a lot about the Cold War, U.S. development aid, African, Caribbean, and South Asian post-colonial history.
This course was a solid overview of recent histories regarding colonialism and post-colonialism.
Great synthesizer course
I learned about global history in the post-colonial era
I learned a lot of things I did not know about modern history, colonialism, and imperialism. I gained a lot of insight into world history and I gained skills to improve my writing.
I learned to analyze historical events and relate them to the present.
I gained a nice general understanding of the arc of postcolonial Third World history since the founding of the United Nations.

An interesting and unique take on critical themes and events in history from the 1950s - 2000s. Oddly structured so I can't fully tell you what the course was about. I learned about very niche aspects of world history.
General understanding of "history" as it is happening in the world now
A great deal of contemporary history was learned. The essential theme of how there are always two sides of one coin was covered widely, which I loved.

I am now a more informed participant in politics because of this class. Understanding recent history is crucial to my development as an adult. I feel generally more educated and empathetic to history.
I gained a deeper appreciation for the historical trends of the 20th century and their impact on today.
I learned some broad narratives of world history since 1960, along with some deep dives into specific interesting topics, and strengthened my skills at writing blog posts.
How to use sources to write essays.
Learnt how to think critically about the world around me today, understand current events more intimately through studying patterns in history and how history is repeating itself around us today.
I gained a much deeper understanding of significant historical events in the past 50 years and how those events have shaped the world today.

I learned how to understand history as a holistic set of processes occurring at the same time rather than the streamlined approach we took in high school. I learned to spot historical patterns and trends.
I did learn a decent amount about decolonization and various texts of the late 1900s. But this course is not about the world circa 2000 which is what I expected it to be
Better insight of international events!
a brief summary of global history from around 1950 to almost today
The most important skill developed was in how to approach contemporary history and in understanding how the trends of the past have led to the trends of the present.
I learned a lot about the Cold War, and read many insightful novels, including Cesaires Discourse on Colonialism.
I learned a lot in this class. It was fantastic. We covered the Cold War up to Trumps presidency and the variation of topics covered was great
Colonialism history.
The class taught me some information helpful in understanding current events, but nothing significant.
Seeing the cold war in a different light
Understanding the key events of 20th century world history
lots of knowledge about the world
In this course I learned how to think about the history fo the 20th century in the context of themes contrasting the global north and south.
Knowledge of some modern history to and themes of imperialism and globalization within the history of the world circa 2000
Colonialism, blog posts, and thoughtful discussions.

I learned a lot about the postcolonial history that has brought us to where we are today. The range of topics and time periods covered helped me understand how recent events are important for our ability to understand the present. I learned how to understand our present by looking at the recent past.
This course helped me gain a much better understanding of how to think historically across circumstances and stories that may seem disparate at first but come together to reveal larger patterns.

strengths - professors and TAs put a lot of time and work into the class, and lectures were very engaging; blogs are a good way to receive grades for the course, and I liked the fact that the grade was entirely based on participation and four works weighted pretty equally

weaknesses - sometimes hard to draw larger themes from the course, as lectures all had different focuses, and we often wouldn't discuss the lectures in section and only the readings; also, definitely harder to understand what was going on as a non-history major. definitely not an introductory-level course. i often felt inferior/confused in section because I had no clue what the TA and history majors were talking about, with their history lingo and very vast, deep prior knowledge

Also want to say Sam Severson is an amazing TA who put a ton of time and effort into every section and giving us feedback on our blogs!

Strengths - Lectures were phenomenal, sections were very helpful
Weaknesses - Readings sometimes were a little disjointed and could be a lot at times
I think the lectures and themes of the course could be more centralized/connected, otherwise it was great.

excellent teaching! very interested course materials. 
There is a lot of reading, but it usually relates to the lectures.
It was incredibly disorganized and all over the place. I was often lost in lecture and then sections would cover entirely different material.

Strengths: My section was great. Didn't know anyone beforehand, but because of the emphasis (40% of grade!!) plus a pretty solid TA, the sections actually turned into interesting discussions. Lectures were basically an entirely separate class from the readings+sections (which are all that really matter for grading purposes) but they're usually very interesting, honestly enjoyable to go to. You won't kill yourself if you have to miss a class but you usually want to go because you hear about some part of history you probably aren't very familiar with.

Weaknesses: If your section/TA is bad, this class would be hell. Section is 40% of the grade and if the TA can't steer a discussion then the entire section suffers. A section asshole could totally cause a miserable semester. Lectures tend to feel disjointed -- good in that it allows for a ton of topic coverage, but bad if you're expecting a traditional "X then Y then Z" history class.

The lectures were very engaging- I loved that the professors always opened with a song and streamlined the discussion based off a theme relative to the class. Everything was incredibly well organized and clear. I also enjoy writing the blog posts- it forces me to be creative and to consider topics through multiple perspectives.
This course needs to be completely reorganized.

Strengths - The blog post assignments encouraged creativity, and I thought they were a great pedagogical tool for students to engage meaningfully and flexibly throughout the semester. Use of multimedia in lectures and syllabus was another strength.
Weaknesses - Co-teaching always comes with issues of consistency, but the nature of this course may have also added to that with a sense of discontinuity at times, jumping around from place to place and decade to decade between lectures and lecturers.
The lectures were excellent and tied in well to the readings.
Boring lectures sometimes and content at times seems disorganized
The professors were pretty weak

Strengths: low workload, interesting material for the most part. I liked how it was a survey course, so you got exposure to a bunch of different historical accounts in various countries

Weaknesses: some lectures were not as engaging as others, and the readings (if you did them) were long

I really liked the way this course used technology; I thought it was very unique. It might have been useful if the instructors had posted their powerpoints as well as lecture outlines for us to use for note-taking.
Strengths: very relevant historical events, very fun and engaging, great discussions in section.
Very broad, very long engagement with class

The greatest strength of this course is the quality of the lecturesboth from Professor Moyn and Professor Magaziner. The greatest weakness, however, is the structure of the course. Many of the lectures, to me, felt like they lacked critical context. The class seemed to jump around the world and across the global timeline in a way that disrupted the continuity of the course.

Strengths are the lack of pressure on tests and the "blog post" structure because it allows us to explore and research the topics we care about as opposed to fitting a set "topic" I loved section w/ Kevin Lord!!!!!!!!!

Weaknesses: the oddly structured lectures that followed no real pattern, the lack of words on the powerpoint that made it difficult to follow, the very specific, often boring or unnecessarily provocative readings

Strengths -- Syllabus organization, readings, TFs, workload

Weaknesses -- Unclear expectations for the blogs, some lectures could be better understood if uploaded online
Daniel Magaziner and Samuel Moyn are incredible lecturers. Each class felt purposeful and organized. They broke concepts down in great detail.
I would have loved more time with each topic. We did get a fair level of breadth in each one but I would have appreciated a bit more.

weaknesses: lectures seemed unorganized and all over the place. hard to follow at times. felt lile names and dates were being thrown at us without real organization or purpose. more of a show of knowledge than a teaching environment. 

strengths: the readings were very insightful and helped guide the course, sections were great, blog posts worked well

Strengths: the lectures were really great and engaging, particularly Professor Magaziner's, and the blog posts, which I thought were a cool way to engage with the material outside of the more traditional essay format

Weaknesses: some of the readings were slightly irrelevant (e.g. I wasn't sure we needed to read the whole bad reactionary novel that was assigned to learn about reactionary movements) and the class overall suffered slightly from a lack of coherence - the lectures were often very cool in isolation but it was a little hard for me to say what the class was "about" or what precisely I learned

The 4 blog posts are open-ended and left me not understanding what the teaching assistants or professors wanted from them... in the end it was apparent that "blog" posts meant mini-history essays in terms of structure and style. Even though the 4 posts were a great way of structuring the written content of this course, allowing students to write on a wide vary of material from the course, there should be substantially more written instructions for the blog posts. But also amazing that the professors allow for blog posts to be revised up until last hand in date in May - if a student wants a higher grade, they can most probably get it if they put the time and effort in.
Excellent paper system, allowed me to write about the aspects of the broad course I was most interested in and the papers weren't so demanding so I had time to do all the assigned readings.

Strengths Magaziner was a very engaging lecture. Weaknesses - there was very little clarity on the blog posts, which resulted in TAs creating their own standards that were not uniform across the board.

A strength is that it enriches a student's common knowledge about world history; however, a weakness would  e the fact that we covered too many topics and thus, did not deeply understand many of them or didn't have enough time to spend on a single one.
There was no common thread to the course and the lectures werent engaging whatsoever. Because there was no midterm or final no one had an incentive to go
Lecture could be more engaging, but loved sections!

Strengths - how many topics are covered
Weaknesses - there is no connection between 2 lectures - every lecture could stand on its own so it's kind of difficult to just pick up and drop off different topics, but that is the way this course is currently designed. Also makes it hard to find general themes throughout the course because it just feels like no material is building on other material

The primary strengths are the professors and the sections.  The primary weakness was that many students took this class expecting it to be a gut and then weren't invested in the course at all which detracted from the experience for other students.
This course was interesting but a bit disorganized as it jumped in many directions without a timeline.
Needs to be more organized. I wasnt sure on any given lecture what exactly it was I was supposed to be getting from that lecture

I think the content and the tone of the class was great. Its incredibly accessible to anyone and is a great poly sci meets history class with great lectures. I would try to incorporate some of the lecture material in the sections / make it clearer why the lectures correspond with the readings.
I wish we covered more recent topics

World c.2000 was an incredible course and by far my favorite this semester. Lectures were detailed and nearly always engaging. I took the class because I loved African Encounters with Colonialism last term and wanted another experience with Prof. Magaziner, who is amazing. I was skeptical that Prof. Moyn would be able to match Prof. Magaziner's enthusiasm and wit, but he did. My TA, Carlos Hernandez, led reflective, careful discussions and solicited our feedback multiple times throughout the semester, which I really appreciated. He also provided great feedback on my blogs.

I would say there are two weaknesses, the first of which is hardly a weakness. I noticed a lot of people did not go to lecture. I was always there, so I saw how quickly the crowd began to thin, lecture after lecture, as more people realized they could write their blogs without referencing more than one or two lectures. I was disappointedclearly these people valued their grades over learning. Perhaps the blogs could somehow require that a certain number of lectures be cited, to force people to show up. Or attendance could be taken. I see this as much more a weakness of the Yale student body than the class, though. Second, the readings sometimes did not connect well to lecture. I struggled with those readings because I didn't have much context for them. Luckily, my TA Carlos did a good job explaining concepts in section. In addition, some weeks we had an entire book to read for section, while others we only had a few articles. I understand I had the syllabus ahead of time and could have planned better for these reading-heavy weeks, but even if I had, I think I would have still appreciated a more balanced reading load. These "weaknesses" did not detract from my overall enjoyment of the class. I hope, for the sake of other students interested in this period of history, it's taught again.

Strengths: Professor Magaziner was very engaging, and I thought the tweets were very fun!

Weaknesses: the course was extremely unorganized, and I felt that there was much disparity between the TFs grading of the blog posts.

The course had a very manageable workload and some interesting lectures.

However, this is one of the most biased courses I have ever taken. The professors have to constantly remind their audience that they are "patriotism" because otherwise their anti-American sentiments and outright communism would lead us to believe otherwise. It's quite sad, to be honest.
the curse jumped around a lot
Great course!!
great course overall

The only strength of this class is the topic it intends to cover: contemporary history. The rest, Im afraid, are all weaknesses. This is a class of slogans and anecdotes, with no rigorous approach to history which is too often used as an ideological instrument to support the professors worldviews. I went to lecture mostly out of self-consciousness and because one could discover a good thing or two but not much more. Other than that, not much could be gained from them.
Professors could do a bit of a better job of denouncing terrorism

I really enjoyed the course and how far reaching many of its lecture topics were. I do believe however that part of people's lack of engagement when I asked my fellow students was due to how far reaching the class seemed to be. A lot of students could not very concisely explain the class or its focus which I think sometimes hurt enthusiasm.
Section was based mostly on reading and less on the class lectures as well
Very flexible but needs to be planned out more.

The lectures were hard to follow and it felt like there was no real structure-- the material jumped all over the place. This course did not have any prerequisites, but you would be far behind if you didn't have a good background in history.

This class was very well taught and the material was very engaging. I also liked the somewhat informal style of the blog posts because they encouraged more personal and thoughtful reflection that wasn't solely historical. I wish more people had attended the lectures and done the readings, but I'm not sure how this would be enforced.
YES!!!

yes! relatively easy and pretty interesting. keep in mind that 40% of your grade is participation, so participating in section is a must. both professors are super enthusiastic and put a ton of time into their lectures. can get lost/confused sometimes because a lot of outside historical knowledge is expected, even though they say its not. but definitely easy workload
YES!
Yes!
Yes
This is a really interesting course, especially for people with an interest in current global affairs. I enjoyed exploring trends that can be seen continuing in the present.
Yes! Great survey course.
Great course for anyone interested in recent history!
No. The professors were disorganized and the class structure was poor. Then we got cold called in section.

Overall, I would. Magaziner and Moyn (the former moreso than the latter) are good lecturers. The readings are SUPER interesting! I enjoyed most of them. We read about anarchist Buddhism and the New World Economic Order and the Chinese infrastructure investments and more. Lectures are basically 100% optional but you will probably want to go at least once a week for blog ideas + to actually learn.

Yes! Engaging and fun and I learned so much. The professors honestly made a huge difference and the course covers as much of global history as is possible in one semester. You learn so much about different dynamics in certain parts of the world.
I would not recommend this course to another student. Find another history class instead.

Absolutely. The easy workload did not lessen my engagement with the material, and allowed me to learn in a low-stress environment. It was great to learn about contemporary phenomenon in a historical context, and the chance to learn from Moyn and Magaziner at the same time is a great opportunity.
I would recommend this course, Magaziner and Moyn give excellent lectures.
Yes
The professors of this class were incredibly weak--we never, ever, finished the lectures. This was basically a rant by two guys without background in the area of study.
Yes, I would recommend this to another student. The workload is very low - just 4 blog posts total, and weekly tweets. Also, you learn a lot about how neoliberalism came about
Yes, I would. I feel that the things I learned in this course would be invaluable to any student of history.
Yes, it was a very fun course and taught me a lot of relevant historical concepts.
Yes.
Good course. I had never studied postcolonial global history, so I learned a lot. Profs and TFs are great (I had Simon)

This is the first time this course was offered, and I would want to see the kinks worked out before recommending it to another student. I really appreciated the low workload (only four blog posts and a weekly Tweet) as well as the strong emphasis on section participation, so I think if the actual course content had the continuity/organization I was looking for, I would definitely recommend it.

Not really. I think taking guts just to take guts is bad and i thought this would be an interesting gut that I would learn from. I learned but I had to really push myself to absorb information because of the odd format. I loved section though and that's one reason I recommend this course.
Yes! Very solid history class that will teach you things about the modern world you definitely did not know
YES! Very engaging and you learn about the events one usually does not learn in high school history books
Yes!! This is all the information everyone should know!
Yes! I found the course very interesting and relevant. I also appreciated the diversity in assignments that it offered with the tweets and blog posts.

I would recommend this class as a fun lecture series with two cool and very thoughtful history professors - in particular, Dan Magaziner's lectures were some of the most beautifully constructed lectures of any I've had at Yale. I suspect he could make any topic interesting. It also had a very low workload (weekly readings, tweets and four thousand-word blog posts). That said, it took on a lot and it's obviously impossible to teach the entire history of the world 1960-present, so I felt that at times it struggled slightly with feeling scattered.
Yes
100%, the lectures were fascinating. Learnt about aspects of history I had no clue about before this course and changed how I view the world around me today.

I would recommend it to anyone who does not have much knowledge in the historical context of issues we are facing today, and does not want to focus on one single topic, but rather explore themes on a larger scale.
Yes!
This was a very easy course so for someone looking for a gut Id recommend it
If interested in the readings!

I would recommend if you need a humanities credit and aren't much of a writer because the writing part of the course is only four 1000-word blogs, but other than that, I probably wouldn't go out of your way to take it because the discontinuity of the lectures was annoying for me at least. However, the material covered is good and can be interesting, stuff you wouldn't learn about in any other course.

Absolutely!  I really enjoyed this course and would recommend it to anyone.  It gives one a broad understanding of recent world history without assuming any prior knowledge.  It's a great course for anyone who's curious about the state of world affairs and how we got here.
Yes. Fulfills humanities credit.
I would definitely recommend this class to anyone. It is so interesting and well-taught and I learned so much  Take this!!
Maybe but only for my TA who was great and for a few of the lectures. Loved the discussion of media and connection to today
Yes! Full stop.
Take this class if you're willing to be fully invested. It offers really interesting perspectives on recent history. It was also fun to tweet each week.
Absolutely - fantastic course. I learned a lot and became a better scholar.

No. The low workload made this course seem manageable, but its extreme un organization made it extremely difficult to understand what was happening. From lecture to lecture I barely saw any connection, and even from slide to slide in a lectures PowerPoint I found myself confused. Not worth it.
Not particularly, though you can do well if you work on the blog posts. The lectures and most readings are nonessential to doing well in the class.
As long as they enjoy modern history
Yes very important in understanding current events
yes because you learn a lot about world history which is always good
I would not recommend this class to any student who hopes to make of their time at Yale one of rigorous intellectual challenge.
No

I would certainly recommend the class to another student. Students loved the blog format that allowed us greater creative freedom when writing and also appreciated the huge amount of new information we came across.

So, I was pretty confused by this course. I initially decided to take it because the syllabus looked amazing and I was super excited to learn more about contemporary history. The lectures, however, were SO disorganized. I appreciated the lecture outlines provided, but there seemed to be no larger themes that tied the lectures together (which was exacerbated by the fact that there were two different lecturers for the class) and my classmates and I were often confused about the overarching narrative we were supposed to derive from each lecture. Also, we were supposed to learn about contemporary history, but there wasn't a single lecture that dealt with it at all. I really would have appreciated some kind of explanatory lecture about what contemporary history meant, why it's important/elusive/useful, and how to approach writing about contemporary events through a historical lens before we were asked to do so for a grade. This leads me to the last point: the blogs. Please, if this is to be taught again, please have a rubric ready for the blogs. At first, I really liked writing the blogs because they allowed me to be creative and pick a specific topic from the course to dive into. However, as time went on, and we got our grades back, there was just such a disparity in the kind of blogs people were writing and the kinds of comments we were receiving that none of us were really sure what we were supposed to be doing. I would really recommend specifying that we use a certain number of readings or lectures and having some examples on canvas for this class, just because it was really difficult to know if we were doing enough. I really don't mean to be overly harsh, but this was just my experience with the course. I liked the lectures and thought they were interesting, and the blogs were definitely a reprieve from the more structured/basic academic assignments we're always asked to write, but I definitely think this course could be improved upon through a little more organization.
Absolutely. Very relevant info- although there is a lot of jumping around from country to country within a lecture.
I would not recommend this course to another student unless they were well-versed in the events circa year 2000.

Yes, I would definitely recommend this course to another student if they are interested in history and current events and want to learn about decolonization in a relatively low-stress and engaging way.
I absolutely would because I think it provides a very helpful base of historical knowledge that helps contextualize the  world we live in today.
